member.summary: for printing sheet vertical centered, otherwise.
member.remarks: Default value for this property is .

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelPrintOptions.HorizontalCentered
member.summary: for printing sheet horizontal centered, otherwise.
member.remarks: Default value for this property is .

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelPrintOptions.PrintHeadings
member.summary: for print headings, otherwise.

remarks.para: Default value for this property is .
Except from printing and exporting to fixed document and rendering formats, such as PDF, XPS and image file formats, is also supported when exporting to HTML file format.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelPrintOptions.PrintGridlines
member.summary: for printing gridlines, otherwise.

remarks.para: Default value for this property is .
Except from printing and exporting to fixed document and rendering formats, such as PDF, XPS and image file formats, is also supported when exporting to HTML file format.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelPrintOptions.PrintPagesInRows
member.summary: for printing pages in rows, otherwise.

remarks.para: Default value for this property is .
This member is supported in printing.

GemBox.Spreadsheet uses enhanced printing services provided with Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF). All pages of a specific will be printed with settings from of that worksheet. Internally, WPF printing uses PrintTicket class to specify page printing settings and value of this member is applied to appropriate member of PrintTicket instance which is used to print all pages of a worksheet with this print options member.
PrintTicket instance which is used to print every page of a worksheet is constructed in following order:

item.description: Based on stream specified in constructor (base print ticket).
Appropriate base print ticket members are set based on instance members values.
Base print ticket is cloned for each worksheet, clone's appropriate members are set based on instance of that worksheet and clone is used to print all pages of that worksheet.

remarks.para: Printing settings which do not exist in nor in can be specified on base print ticket (which stream is passed to constructor).

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelPrintOptions.PrintBlackWhite
member.summary: for printing in black and white, otherwise.

remarks.para: Default value for this property is .
This value is currently ignored when exporting a document to PDF, XPS or image file formats.
This member is supported in printing.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelPrintOptions.AutomaticPageBreakScalingFactor
member.summary: Scaling factor for automatic page breaks.

remarks.para: Unit is one percent. Value must be between 10 and 400.
Default value for this property is 100.
MS Excel inserts automatic page breaks depending on this scaling factor. Smaller it gets, bigger will be the distance between the two automatic page breaks.
If you set this property, will automatically be set to .

member.exception: Value is out of 10 to 400 range.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelPrintOptions.VerticalPrintResolution
member.summary: Vertical print resolution in DPI (dots per inch).

remarks.para: Default value for this property is 0.
This value is currently ignored when exporting a document to PDF, XPS or image file formats.
This member is supported in printing.

GemBox.Spreadsheet uses enhanced printing services provided with Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF). All pages of a specific will be printed with settings from of that worksheet. Internally, WPF printing uses PrintTicket class to specify page printing settings and value of this member is applied to appropriate member of PrintTicket instance which is used to print all pages of a worksheet with this print options member.
PrintTicket instance which is used to print every page of a worksheet is constructed in following order:

item.description: Based on stream specified in constructor (base print ticket).
Appropriate base print ticket members are set based on instance members values.
Base print ticket is cloned for each worksheet, clone's appropriate members are set based on instance of that worksheet and clone is used to print all pages of that worksheet.

remarks.para: Printing settings which do not exist in nor in can be specified on base print ticket (which stream is passed to constructor).

remarks.para: Default value for this property is 1.
This value is currently ignored when exporting a document to PDF, XPS or image file formats.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelWorksheet
member.summary: Excel worksheet is a table with additional properties, identified by a unique name.

remarks.para: Worksheet in Microsoft Excel has limited size. Number of rows () is limited to ExcelFile.MaxRows. Number of columns () is limited to ExcelFile.MaxColumns. A specific cell () can be accessed either trough ExcelRow.Cells, ExcelColumn.Cells or ExcelWorksheet.Cells property. Whichever property used, there are two distinct methods of getting a cell reference; using name and using index. For example, full name of cell in top left corner of a worksheet is "A1". Translated to indexes, same cell would be 0,0 (zero row and zero column). If using ExcelRow.Cells or ExcelColumn.Cells to access a specific cell, only partial name or partial index must be used, providing unknown column or row information.

Note that the cells are internally allocated in rows and not in columns. ExcelColumn objects are created only if they have non-standard width or style, or they are accessed directly. So, while ExcelRowCollection.Count shows number of rows occupied with data, ExcelColumnCollection.Count does not say which Column is the last one occupied with data!
If you want to read all data in a sheet, use ExcelRow.AllocatedCells property.
If you want to find last column occupied with data, use method.

member.seealso: Referencing ExcelCell and CellRange in C# and VB.NET

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelWorksheet.NamedRanges
member.summary: Gets containing descriptive names which are used to represent cells, ranges of cells, formulas, or constant values.
member.remarks: You can use the labels of columns and rows on a worksheet to refer to the cells within those columns and rows. Or you can create descriptive names to represent cells, ranges of cells, formulas, or constant values. Labels can be used in formulas that refer to data on the same worksheet; if you want to represent a range on another worksheet, use a name. You can also create 3-D names that represent the same cell or range of cells across multiple worksheets.
member.seealso: ExcelCell.Formula

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelWorksheet.IgnoredErrors

summary.para: Gets the ignored errors applied on cell ranges of this sheet.
Currently supported in XLS and XLSX.

member.value: The ignored errors applied on cell ranges of this sheet.

remarks.para: A cell is considered to have an error condition when it meets one of the conditions specified in the member. For example, if a cell is formatted as text but contains a numeric value, this is considered to be a potential error because the number won't be treated as a number, for example, in calculations.

Note that this is simply a guess by the implementing application, and a recommendation to the user. Cells with the errors specified in may have perfectly valid reasons for being in such a state, for example a cell formatted as text which contains numeric Postal Codes or Order numbers. It is useful to format these cells as text so that leading zeros remain as part of the value instead of being removed.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ExcelWorksheet.PivotTables

summary.para: Gets the collection of all s contained in this worksheet.
Currently supported in XLSX only.

member.value: The collection of all s contained in this worksheet.

remarks.para: Pivot Tables are used to arrange and aggregate complicated data and drill down on details.
Source of data for Pivot Table can be:

item.description: Worksheet - cell range, named range, table, etc.
External - database, OLAP cube, textual file, web query, etc.
Other - multiple consolidation ranges in the workbook, another Pivot Table, etc.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently supports creating only worksheet source.
All other sources are supported through preservation (to correctly round-trip to XLSX format).

remarks.para: Source of the data for Pivot Table contains following information:

item.description: Scheme - data source fields/columns, its data types, etc.
Data - actual data source records.

remarks.para: Pivot Table does not directly reference its data source, but instead it references a cache of a data source. Cache of a data source contains an in-memory copy of data source scheme and, optionally, data and is stored in a workbook which may contain multiple caches of various sources of data.

Cache can be updated/refreshed from a data source automatically (for example, when opening a workbook) or on request. Cache is used to provide better performance of Pivot Table functionality which requires frequent access to data records and their values and to enable sharing the same data source between multiple Pivot Tables.

GemBox.Spreadsheet represents cache with a type. Cache source is represented with a type (and its sub-types) and can be accessed from a property. instances are stored in a collection. currently doesn't store the actual cached records (it stores only scheme - fields and their properties), but instead Microsoft Excel is instructed to update the record cache from the data source when opening a workbook.

is created from a with the specified name and the specified cell in the worksheet where it is placed using the method. contains the collection which elements can be moved into the following Pivot Table areas:

item.description: Report Filter Area represented by collection.
Row Axis represented by collection.
Column Axis represented by collection.
Values Area represented by collection.

remarks.para: Each (non-calculated) can contain zero or more s which are used for filtering and grouping by a specific value.

Except using fields defined in Pivot Table data source (more precisely, in ) which cannot be removed, Pivot Table can also define calculated s and calculated s which use a formula to specify their values. Calculated can be added using a method and removed using a method. Property tells if a field is calculated or is a field from the data source. Calculated is automatically moved to a Values Area ( collection) and only Values Area can contain calculated s. Calculated can be added using a method and removed using a method. Property tells if an item is calculated.

note.para: If calculated is added/removed in one , then it is also added/removed from all other s which reference the same .
Since adding/removing calculated s means changing the data scheme, which is defined in , actual modification is made in and propagated to all s which are referencing it.

remarks.para: s can be re-ordered in a specific area using the method. s can be re-ordered using the method.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently does not provide functionality to read/calculate the actual data from the .
It provides the functionality to arrange and customize s, s and appearance.

Because of that data is not rendered/written to other output formats like PDF, HTML, etc. When output XLSX file with Pivot Table is opened in Microsoft Excel application, its data is automatically retrieved and calculated from the data source by Microsoft Excel.

member.seealso: Create Excel Pivot Tables in C# and VB.NET

This property needs to be set to value of type ushort (property is of type int because ushort is not CLS compliant). If you don't know which password hash corresponds to determinant password, make excel file using MS Excel, load it using GemBox.Spreadsheet, and read this property. Then reuse that value in your project.

member.summary: Extracts data to DataTable with the same column order as it is in ExcelWorksheet.

remarks.para: DataTable has to have all the columns defined before calling this method. Because DataColumnMapping objects are not used in this method, columns in DataTable have to have the same order as columns in ExcelWorksheet (starting from column defined in startColumn argument).
You can customize error handling by using .

DataTable column type and corresponding cell value type need to be 'similar' data types. If that's not the case, then exception would be thrown. Note that numbers and string are not 'similar' data types. Numbers wouldn't be automatically converted to strings because of culture issues; someone would expect the number 12.4 is converted to "12.4" and someone else to "12,4". To make custom conversion, use .

summary.para: Represents the style of fill pattern being used for a cell format.
Currently supported only in XLS and XLSX. For all other formats it defaults to either or .

remarks.para: Conceptually, cell formatting is divided into following groups:

item.description: Number - indicates how to format and render the numeric value of a cell. Associated property is .
Alignment - formatting information pertaining to text alignment in cells. Associated properties are , , , , , and .
Font - defines the properties for the used font. Associated property is .
Border - expresses a single set of cell border formats (left, right, top, bottom and diagonal). Associated property is .
Fill - specifies fill formatting (pattern or gradient). Associated property is .
Protection - contains protection properties associated with the cell. Associated properties are and .

remarks.para: Additional properties not associated with any formatting group are:

item.description: - name of the referenced workbook style.
- to store numeric value of a cell as text; otherwise, .
- if referenced workbook style is default () and there are no additional modifications of cell formatting; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Workbook contains a set of master styles which can be referenced by multiple cells.
Workbook must always contain at least one master style which cannot be removed and is, by default, referenced by all cells. This default style is .
Workbook style can either be built-in or user-defined. Built-in style is accessible from workbook styles via enumeration.

Cell formatting group (Number, Alignment, Font, Border, Fill or Protection) (and its associated properties) is resolved from referenced workbook (master) style, unless cell formatting group or its associated property is modified.

Cell formatting is available for one or more cells through property which is available on and types. Cell formatting specified on and types through property is simply propagated to cell formatting of its .

note.para: For performance reasons, cell formatting on is resolved based just on its top-left cell formatting, except borders which are resolved based on corner cells depending on border side.
Setting cell formatting property on is propagated to each cell in a range.

remarks.para: To set workbook (master) style to one or more cells, simply assign it to property.

note.para: Preferable way to modify formatting property of multiple cells is to get to which all those cells belong, and use property of that range to make the modification.

If modifying multiple formatting properties of a , without preserving unmodified formatting properties, preferable way is to create new instance of , make modifications on it, and assign it to property of that range.

remarks.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet internally takes care not to allocate unnecessary cells when formatting a range of cells (for example, when formatting all worksheet cells) and to cache formatting information of equally formatted cells, at the appropriate time, to reduce memory footprint.

summary.para: The fill style is none (no fill).

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.FontSettings.FontsBaseResourceLocation

summary.para: Gets or sets the base resource location where component looks for fonts specified as resources inside the local or referenced assembly.
Read Remarks for details about the format of the for desktop and web applications.

member.value: The base resource location where component looks for fonts specified as resources inside the local or referenced assembly.

note.para: When you add fonts as resources to your application, make sure you are setting the <Resource> element when targeting .NET Framework or when targeting .NET Core with enabled WPF.
Otherwise, use <EmbeddedResource> element for the build action.

remarks.para: Following image shows an example of a Windows Console project structure with font files added as resources.
Following table illustrates the various base resource locations that you can specify to use fonts from the above Windows Console project structure.
Resource locations consist of required and adjustable parts.

tr.td: Font resource files are in the root of local assembly.
Font resource files are in the subfolder of local assembly.
Font resource files are in the root of referenced assembly.
Font resource files are in the subfolder of referenced assembly.

remarks.para: Following image shows an example of a Web ASP.NET project structure with font files added as resources.
Following table illustrates the various base resource locations that you can specify to use fonts from the above Web ASP.NET project structure.
Since ASP.NET assembly is actually a class library referenced from ASP.NET web server, resource location must always include ;component part.

tr.td: Font resource files are in the root of local assembly.
Font resource files are in the subfolder of local assembly.
Font resource files are in the root of referenced assembly.
Font resource files are in the subfolder of referenced assembly.

Pack URIs in WPF

member.param: The path to which to save the drawing.
member.exception: If file extension is not specified or not supported. If file extension is not recognized, use method overload instead.
member.remarks:
File extension that is extracted from the is used to create the appropriate derived class instance that is then passed to the method.
Following file extensions are supported:
Portable Document Format: .pdf
XML Paper Specification: .xps
Portable Network Graphics: .png
Joint Photographic Experts Group: .jpeg, .jpg
Bitmap: .bmp
Tagged Image File Format: .tiff, .tif
Windows Media Photo: .wdp

member.name: M:GemBox.Spreadsheet.FormattedExcelDrawing.Save(System.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Saves the drawing to a System.Web.HttpResponse or System.Web.HttpResponseBase output stream or a System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage and sets appropriate HTTP response headers (Content-Type and Content-Disposition). Use this method in ASP.NET application to send the drawing to a client browser. File format is resolved from extension. See remarks why parameter is of type .
member.param: System.Web.HttpResponse object that can be retrieved through the Response property of the System.Web.HttpApplication, System.Web.HttpContext, System.Web.UI.Page or System.Web.UI.UserControl classes or System.Web.HttpResponseBase object or System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage object.
File name that will be presented in client browser when downloading a file.
member.exception: If file extension is not specified or not supported. If file extension is not recognized, use method overload instead.

remarks.note: Supported only if updating the whole page with a postback and not if doing partial-page updates (when you use UpdatePanel controls to update selected regions of a page).
remarks.para: This method accepts rather than HttpResponse, HttpResponseBase or HttpResponseMessage because otherwise GemBox.Document assembly would have a dependency on System.Web or System.Net.Http assemblies and could not be used in applications which target Client Profile .NET Framework.
HttpResponse can be retrieved through the Response property of the HttpApplication, HttpContext, Page or UserControl classes.
For supported file extensions, see remarks for method.

member.seealso: Export Excel file with ASP.NET

summary.para: Represents a shading style and variant of a gradient fill effect.
Gradient fill is currently supported in XLSX and partially in rendering formats (PDF, XPS and image formats).

remarks.para: Conceptually, cell formatting is divided into following groups:

item.description: Number - indicates how to format and render the numeric value of a cell. Associated property is .
Alignment - formatting information pertaining to text alignment in cells. Associated properties are , , , , , and .
Font - defines the properties for the used font. Associated property is .
Border - expresses a single set of cell border formats (left, right, top, bottom and diagonal). Associated property is .
Fill - specifies fill formatting (pattern or gradient). Associated property is .
Protection - contains protection properties associated with the cell. Associated properties are and .

remarks.para: Additional properties not associated with any formatting group are:

item.description: - name of the referenced workbook style.
- to store numeric value of a cell as text; otherwise, .
- if referenced workbook style is default () and there are no additional modifications of cell formatting; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Workbook contains a set of master styles which can be referenced by multiple cells.
Workbook must always contain at least one master style which cannot be removed and is, by default, referenced by all cells. This default style is .
Workbook style can either be built-in or user-defined. Built-in style is accessible from workbook styles via enumeration.

Cell formatting group (Number, Alignment, Font, Border, Fill or Protection) (and its associated properties) is resolved from referenced workbook (master) style, unless cell formatting group or its associated property is modified.

Cell formatting is available for one or more cells through property which is available on and types. Cell formatting specified on and types through property is simply propagated to cell formatting of its .

note.para: For performance reasons, cell formatting on is resolved based just on its top-left cell formatting, except borders which are resolved based on corner cells depending on border side.
Setting cell formatting property on is propagated to each cell in a range.

remarks.para: To set workbook (master) style to one or more cells, simply assign it to property.

note.para: Preferable way to modify formatting property of multiple cells is to get to which all those cells belong, and use property of that range to make the modification.

If modifying multiple formatting properties of a , without preserving unmodified formatting properties, preferable way is to create new instance of , make modifications on it, and assign it to property of that range.

remarks.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet internally takes care not to allocate unnecessary cells when formatting a range of cells (for example, when formatting all worksheet cells) and to cache formatting information of equally formatted cells, at the appropriate time, to reduce memory footprint.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.GradientShadingStyle.None
member.summary: Cell doesn't have any gradient fill effect.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.GradientShadingStyle.HorizontalHigh
member.summary: Linear gradient where the first color starts at the top side of the cell and blends horizontally with the second color which starts at the bottom side of the cell [1 - 2].

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.GradientShadingStyle.HorizontalLow
member.summary: Linear gradient where the first color starts at the bottom side of the cell and blends horizontally with the second color which starts at the top side of the cell [2 - 1].

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.GradientShadingStyle.Horizontal
member.summary: Linear gradient where the first color starts at the top and bottom sides of the cell and blends horizontally with the second color which starts in the middle of the cell [1 - 2 - 1].

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.GradientShadingStyle.VerticalLow
member.summary: Linear gradient where the first color starts at the left side of the cell and blends vertically with the second color which starts at the right side of the cell [1 | 2].

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.GradientShadingStyle.VerticalHigh
member.summary: Linear gradient where the first color starts at the right side of the cell and blends vertically with the second color which starts at the left side of the cell [2 | 1].

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.GradientShadingStyle.Vertical
member.summary: Linear gradient where the first color starts at the left and right sides of the cell and blends vertically with the second color which starts in the middle of the cell [1 | 2 | 1].

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.GradientShadingStyle.DiagonalUpHigh

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.HorizontalAlignmentStyle
member.summary: Represents available horizontal alignment options used in member.

remarks.para: Conceptually, cell formatting is divided into following groups:

item.description: Number - indicates how to format and render the numeric value of a cell. Associated property is .
Alignment - formatting information pertaining to text alignment in cells. Associated properties are , , , , , and .
Font - defines the properties for the used font. Associated property is .
Border - expresses a single set of cell border formats (left, right, top, bottom and diagonal). Associated property is .
Fill - specifies fill formatting (pattern or gradient). Associated property is .
Protection - contains protection properties associated with the cell. Associated properties are and .

remarks.para: Additional properties not associated with any formatting group are:

item.description: - name of the referenced workbook style.
- to store numeric value of a cell as text; otherwise, .
- if referenced workbook style is default () and there are no additional modifications of cell formatting; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Workbook contains a set of master styles which can be referenced by multiple cells.
Workbook must always contain at least one master style which cannot be removed and is, by default, referenced by all cells. This default style is .
Workbook style can either be built-in or user-defined. Built-in style is accessible from workbook styles via enumeration.

Cell formatting group (Number, Alignment, Font, Border, Fill or Protection) (and its associated properties) is resolved from referenced workbook (master) style, unless cell formatting group or its associated property is modified.

Cell formatting is available for one or more cells through property which is available on and types. Cell formatting specified on and types through property is simply propagated to cell formatting of its .

note.para: For performance reasons, cell formatting on is resolved based just on its top-left cell formatting, except borders which are resolved based on corner cells depending on border side.
Setting cell formatting property on is propagated to each cell in a range.

remarks.para: To set workbook (master) style to one or more cells, simply assign it to property.

note.para: Preferable way to modify formatting property of multiple cells is to get to which all those cells belong, and use property of that range to make the modification.

If modifying multiple formatting properties of a , without preserving unmodified formatting properties, preferable way is to create new instance of , make modifications on it, and assign it to property of that range.

remarks.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet internally takes care not to allocate unnecessary cells when formatting a range of cells (for example, when formatting all worksheet cells) and to cache formatting information of equally formatted cells, at the appropriate time, to reduce memory footprint.

summary.para: The horizontal alignment is general-aligned.
Text data is left-aligned.
Numbers, dates, and times are right-aligned.
Boolean types are centered.
Changing the alignment does not change the type of data.
The horizontal alignment is left-aligned.
Aligns contents at the left edge of the cell.
If an amount is specified, the contents of the cell is indented from the left by the specified number of character spaces.
The character spaces are based on the default font and font size for the workbook ( style).

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.HorizontalAlignmentStyle.Center
member.summary: The horizontal alignment is centered, meaning the text is centered across the cell.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.HorizontalAlignmentStyle.Right
member.summary: The horizontal alignment is right-aligned, meaning that cell contents are aligned at the right edge of the cell.

summary.para: Indicates that the value of the cell should be filled across the entire width of the cell.
This option is currently not supported in PDF, XPS and image file formats and defaults to .
The horizontal alignment is justified (flush left and right).
For each line of text, aligns each line of the wrapped text in a cell to the right and left (except the last line).
If no single line of text wraps in the cell, then the text is not justified.
The horizontal alignment is centered across multiple cells.
This option is currently not supported in PDF, XPS and image file formats and defaults to .
Indicates that each 'word' in each line of text inside the cell is evenly distributed across the width of the cell, with flush right and left margins.
When there is also an value to apply, both the left and right side of the cell are padded by the indent value.
A 'word' is a set of characters with no space character in them.
Two lines inside a cell are separated by a carriage return.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredError
member.summary: Represents a single ignored error for a range of cells.

remarks.para: A cell is considered to have an error condition when it meets one of the conditions specified in the member. For example, if a cell is formatted as text but contains a numeric value, this is considered to be a potential error because the number won't be treated as a number, for example, in calculations.

Note that this is simply a guess by the implementing application, and a recommendation to the user. Cells with the errors specified in may have perfectly valid reasons for being in such a state, for example a cell formatted as text which contains numeric Postal Codes or Order numbers. It is useful to format these cells as text so that leading zeros remain as part of the value instead of being removed.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredErrorTypes
member.summary: Represents an ignored error conditions.

remarks.para: A cell is considered to have an error condition when it meets one of the conditions specified in the member. For example, if a cell is formatted as text but contains a numeric value, this is considered to be a potential error because the number won't be treated as a number, for example, in calculations.

Note that this is simply a guess by the implementing application, and a recommendation to the user. Cells with the errors specified in may have perfectly valid reasons for being in such a state, for example a cell formatted as text which contains numeric Postal Codes or Order numbers. It is useful to format these cells as text so that leading zeros remain as part of the value instead of being removed.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredErrorTypes.None
member.summary: Do not ignore any error.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredErrorTypes.EvaluationError
member.summary: Ignore errors when cells contain formulas that result in an error such as '#VALUE!' or '#DIV/0!'.

summary.para: Ignore errors when cells contain a value different from a calculated column formula for tables.
In other words, for a calculated column, a cell in that column is considered to have an error if its formula is different from the calculated column formula, or doesn't contain a formula at all.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredErrorTypes.TwoDigitTextYear
member.summary: Ignore errors when cells contain dates in text form with years represented as 2 digits.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredErrorTypes.NumberStoredAsText
member.summary: Ignore errors when numbers are formatted as text or are preceded by an apostrophe.

summary.para: Ignore errors when a formula in a region of your worksheet differs from other formulas in the same region.

For example, if the formula in cell A1 is "=B1", and the formula in cell A3 is "=B3", but the formula in cell A2 is not "=B2" but instead "=C2", then A1 and A3 both refer to the cell one column to their right, but A2 does not and so is inconsistent with them.
Ignore errors when formulas omit certain cells in a region.
For example, if there is data in cells A1:A100 and formula contains the reference "=SUM(A1:A98)".

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredErrorTypes.UnlockedFormula
member.summary: Ignore errors when unlocked (editable) cells in the locked sheet contain formulas.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredErrorTypes.EmptyCellReference
member.summary: Ignore errors when formulas refer to empty cells.

summary.para: Ignore errors when a cell's value in a Table does not comply with the Data Validation rules specified.
For example, when a cell's value is inconsistent with the column data type for Tables connected to SharePoint data.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IgnoredErrorTypes.All
member.summary: Ignore all errors.

If only one of the or is specified, then the specified dimension will be respected and other dimension will be calculated so that original aspect ratio is maintained.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ImageSaveOptions.MetafileScaleFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the scaling factor for rendering metafile (WMF and EMF) images. Greater scaling factor improves quality but also increases file size. Default value is 1.
member.value: The metafile scale factor for rendering metafile (WMF and EMF) images.

remarks.para: Windows Metafile Format (WMF) and Enhanced Metafile Format (EMF) are vector image formats which contain a series of graphics drawing commands usually executed in Windows GDI layer.
Metafile drawing commands could also be executed in PDF (or XPS) file which is also vector format, but for that Metafile drawing commands would have to be converted to PDF drawing commands.

GemBox.Document currently doesn't perform this conversion of drawing commands, instead it uses Windows GDI to execute Metafile drawing commands into bitmap which is then encoded to PNG format and embedded into PDF file.
specifies the size of the bitmap surface, based from the original Metafile surface size, into which Metafile should be drawn / rasterized.

PDF viewer will still scale the bitmap to the original Metafile size, but if the page is zoomed or viewed on a larger surface, quality of the image will be better since it contains more pixels / dots which will become visible while PDF viewer scales down the image.

increases the quality of the Metafile image in PDF file, but it also increases the size of the PDF file because greater means greater bitmap surface and more space to store bitmap pixel / color data. PNG encoding / compression helps in reducing the space requirement and for complex Metafiles (with a lot of drawing instructions), of 5 or even greater, might not incur any space overhead relative to the original (complex) Metafile.
Default value for is 1.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.IndividualBorder
member.summary: Represents single border type of a cell.

remarks.para: Diagonal-up ( / ) and diagonal-down ( / ) always share the same color and line style.
Conceptually, cell formatting is divided into following groups:

item.description: Number - indicates how to format and render the numeric value of a cell. Associated property is .
Alignment - formatting information pertaining to text alignment in cells. Associated properties are , , , , , and .
Font - defines the properties for the used font. Associated property is .
Border - expresses a single set of cell border formats (left, right, top, bottom and diagonal). Associated property is .
Fill - specifies fill formatting (pattern or gradient). Associated property is .
Protection - contains protection properties associated with the cell. Associated properties are and .

remarks.para: Additional properties not associated with any formatting group are:

item.description: - name of the referenced workbook style.
- to store numeric value of a cell as text; otherwise, .
- if referenced workbook style is default () and there are no additional modifications of cell formatting; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Workbook contains a set of master styles which can be referenced by multiple cells.
Workbook must always contain at least one master style which cannot be removed and is, by default, referenced by all cells. This default style is .
Workbook style can either be built-in or user-defined. Built-in style is accessible from workbook styles via enumeration.

Cell formatting group (Number, Alignment, Font, Border, Fill or Protection) (and its associated properties) is resolved from referenced workbook (master) style, unless cell formatting group or its associated property is modified.

Cell formatting is available for one or more cells through property which is available on and types. Cell formatting specified on and types through property is simply propagated to cell formatting of its .

note.para: For performance reasons, cell formatting on is resolved based just on its top-left cell formatting, except borders which are resolved based on corner cells depending on border side.
Setting cell formatting property on is propagated to each cell in a range.

remarks.para: To set workbook (master) style to one or more cells, simply assign it to property.

note.para: Preferable way to modify formatting property of multiple cells is to get to which all those cells belong, and use property of that range to make the modification.

If modifying multiple formatting properties of a , without preserving unmodified formatting properties, preferable way is to create new instance of , make modifications on it, and assign it to property of that range.

remarks.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet internally takes care not to allocate unnecessary cells when formatting a range of cells (for example, when formatting all worksheet cells) and to cache formatting information of equally formatted cells, at the appropriate time, to reduce memory footprint.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.NamedRangeCollection
member.summary: Collection of the descriptive names which are used to represent cells, ranges of cells, formulas, or constant values.
member.remarks: You can use the labels of columns and rows on a worksheet to refer to the cells within those columns and rows. Or you can create descriptive names to represent cells, ranges of cells, formulas, or constant values. Labels can be used in formulas that refer to data on the same worksheet; if you want to represent a range on another worksheet, use a name. You can also create 3-D names that represent the same cell or range of cells across multiple worksheets.
member.seealso: ExcelCell.Formula

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PdfConformanceLevel
member.summary: Represents levels of conformance for PDF documents.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PdfConformanceLevel.None
member.summary: No conformance.

summary.para: PDF/A-1 is based on PDF version 1.4, which first appeared in 2001. All resources (images, graphics, typographic characters) must be embedded within the PDF/A document itself. A PDF/A file requires precise, platform-independent colour data using ICC profiles, and XMP for the document metadata. Transparent elements, some forms of compression (LZW, JPEG2000), PDF layers, and certain actions or JavaScript are forbidden. A PDF/A file must not be password-protected. PDF/A-1 expressly supports embedded digital signatures and the use of hyperlinks.

Level A (Accessible) meets all requirements for the standard, including the logical structure of the document and its correct reading order. Text must be extractable and the logical structure must match the natural reading order. Fonts used must meet stringent requirements. This PDF/A level can usually only be met by converting born-digital documents.

PDF/A-1 is based on PDF version 1.4, which first appeared in 2001. All resources (images, graphics, typographic characters) must be embedded within the PDF/A document itself. A PDF/A file requires precise, platform-independent colour data using ICC profiles, and XMP for the document metadata. Transparent elements, some forms of compression (LZW, JPEG2000), PDF layers, and certain actions or JavaScript are forbidden. A PDF/A file must not be password-protected. PDF/A-1 expressly supports embedded digital signatures and the use of hyperlinks.

Level B (Basic) guarantees that the content of the document can be unambiguously reproduced. Level B files are easier to create than Level A, but Level B does not guarantee 100% text extraction or searchability. It does not necessarily mean that the content can be reused without any problems. Scanned paper documents can usually be converted to PDF/A Conformance Level B without any extra work.

PDF/A-2 was published in 2011 as "ISO 19005-2". Based on PDF version 1.7, which has since been standardised as "ISO 32000-1", it makes use of this version’s new features. This means PDF/A-2 allows JPEG2000 compression, transparent elements and PDF layers. PDF/A-2 also allows you to embed OpenType fonts and supports PAdES(PDF Advanced Electronic Signatures)-compliant digital signatures. One particularly important innovation is the "container" function: PDF/A files can be embedded within a PDF/A-2 document.

Level A (Accessible) meets all requirements for the standard, including the logical structure of the document and its correct reading order. Text must be extractable and the logical structure must match the natural reading order. Fonts used must meet stringent requirements. This PDF/A level can usually only be met by converting born-digital documents.

PDF/A-2 was published in 2011 as "ISO 19005-2". Based on PDF version 1.7, which has since been standardised as "ISO 32000-1", it makes use of this version’s new features. This means PDF/A-2 allows JPEG2000 compression, transparent elements and PDF layers. PDF/A-2 also allows you to embed OpenType fonts and supports PAdES(PDF Advanced Electronic Signatures)-compliant digital signatures. One particularly important innovation is the "container" function: PDF/A files can be embedded within a PDF/A-2 document.

Level B (Basic) guarantees that the content of the document can be unambiguously reproduced. Level B files are easier to create than Level A, but Level B does not guarantee 100% text extraction or searchability. It does not necessarily mean that the content can be reused without any problems. Scanned paper documents can usually be converted to PDF/A Conformance Level B without any extra work.

PDF/A-2 was published in 2011 as "ISO 19005-2". Based on PDF version 1.7, which has since been standardised as "ISO 32000-1", it makes use of this version’s new features. This means PDF/A-2 allows JPEG2000 compression, transparent elements and PDF layers. PDF/A-2 also allows you to embed OpenType fonts and supports PAdES(PDF Advanced Electronic Signatures)-compliant digital signatures. One particularly important innovation is the "container" function: PDF/A files can be embedded within a PDF/A-2 document.
Level U (Unicode) was introduced along with PDF/A-2. It expands Conformance Level B to specify that all text can be mapped to standard Unicode character codes.

PDF/A-3 has been available since October 2012. A PDF/A-3 document allows you to embed any file format desired – not just PDF/A documents. For example, a PDF/A-3 file can contain the original file from which it was generated. The PDF/A standard does not regulate the suitability of these embedded files for archiving.

This PDF/A level can usually only be met by converting born-digital documents.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PdfDigitalSignatureSaveOptions
member.summary: Represents a class that stores details for signing a workbook saved to a Portable Document Format (PDF) with a digital signature.

remarks.para: Workbook will be digitally signed when saved to a PDF if , or is specified, if instance is created with method or if Sign(Stream) method is overridden, otherwise it will be saved but not digitally signed.
remarks.note: To use on .NET Standard, make sure your project references NuGet package System.Security.Cryptography.Pkcs.

member.seealso: PDF digital signature examples

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class from the specified signer.
member.param: A delegate that returns the format of the signature content that the signer produces.
A delegate that returns the estimated length of the signature content (in bytes) that should be large enough to contain the entire data returned by the delegate.

A delegate called when saving the PDF file that takes the PDF file stream (without signature's Contents entry) as an input and returns the signature that will be set as the value of the signature's Contents entry.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PdfSaveOptions.Permissions
member.summary: Gets or sets the operations that are allowed to a user on an encrypted PDF document.

remarks.para: Generated PDF document will be encrypted if any of the following conditions are satisfied:

item.description: is different than .
is not or .
is not or .

remarks.para: Both and are optional but with the following consequences:

item.description: If is different than and is not specified, component will generate random .
Using , also known as owner password, without is not secure. It relies on PDF viewer software to respect specified restrictions, but it may choose not to do so.
Using , also known as user password, is potentially very secure. It or is required for decrypting and viewing the document.

When is specified, PDF viewer application will prompt for password to decrypt and present the document. If entered password is , document will be decrypted and presented with specified enforced. Otherwise, if entered password is , document will be decrypted and presented without any restrictions.

remarks.para: and cannot be equal, otherwise exception is thrown.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PdfSaveOptions.ImageDpi
member.summary: Gets or sets the saved images DPI.
member.value: The saved images DPI.
member.remarks:
This property controls the image quality for all images in the file. Larger value results in better-quality images but increases the file size. Setting this property to 0 will disable image optimization. Standard DPI values are:
330 - Good quality for HD displays
220 - Good quality for most printers and displays
150 - Good quality for web pages and projectors
96 - Good quality for smaller file sizes

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PdfSaveOptions.MetafileScaleFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the scaling factor for rendering metafile (WMF and EMF) images. Greater scaling factor improves quality but also increases file size. Default value is 1.
member.value: The metafile scale factor for rendering metafile (WMF and EMF) images.

remarks.para: Windows Metafile Format (WMF) and Enhanced Metafile Format (EMF) are vector image formats which contain a series of graphics drawing commands usually executed in Windows GDI layer.
Metafile drawing commands could also be executed in PDF (or XPS) file which is also vector format, but for that Metafile drawing commands would have to be converted to PDF drawing commands.

GemBox.Document currently doesn't perform this conversion of drawing commands, instead it uses Windows GDI to execute Metafile drawing commands into bitmap which is then encoded to PNG format and embedded into PDF file.
specifies the size of the bitmap surface, based from the original Metafile surface size, into which Metafile should be drawn / rasterized.

PDF viewer will still scale the bitmap to the original Metafile size, but if the page is zoomed or viewed on a larger surface, quality of the image will be better since it contains more pixels / dots which will become visible while PDF viewer scales down the image.

increases the quality of the Metafile image in PDF file, but it also increases the size of the PDF file because greater means greater bitmap surface and more space to store bitmap pixel / color data. PNG encoding / compression helps in reducing the space requirement and for complex Metafiles (with a lot of drawing instructions), of 5 or even greater, might not incur any space overhead relative to the original (complex) Metafile.
Default value for is 1.

member.remarks:

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PivotTables.PivotAreaFieldCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of visible (row, column, page or data) s.

remarks.para: Pivot Tables are used to arrange and aggregate complicated data and drill down on details.
Source of data for Pivot Table can be:

item.description: Worksheet - cell range, named range, table, etc.
External - database, OLAP cube, textual file, web query, etc.
Other - multiple consolidation ranges in the workbook, another Pivot Table, etc.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently supports creating only worksheet source.
All other sources are supported through preservation (to correctly round-trip to XLSX format).

remarks.para: Source of the data for Pivot Table contains following information:

item.description: Scheme - data source fields/columns, its data types, etc.
Data - actual data source records.

remarks.para: Pivot Table does not directly reference its data source, but instead it references a cache of a data source. Cache of a data source contains an in-memory copy of data source scheme and, optionally, data and is stored in a workbook which may contain multiple caches of various sources of data.

Cache can be updated/refreshed from a data source automatically (for example, when opening a workbook) or on request. Cache is used to provide better performance of Pivot Table functionality which requires frequent access to data records and their values and to enable sharing the same data source between multiple Pivot Tables.

GemBox.Spreadsheet represents cache with a type. Cache source is represented with a type (and its sub-types) and can be accessed from a property. instances are stored in a collection. currently doesn't store the actual cached records (it stores only scheme - fields and their properties), but instead Microsoft Excel is instructed to update the record cache from the data source when opening a workbook.

is created from a with the specified name and the specified cell in the worksheet where it is placed using the method. contains the collection which elements can be moved into the following Pivot Table areas:

item.description: Report Filter Area represented by collection.
Row Axis represented by collection.
Column Axis represented by collection.
Values Area represented by collection.

remarks.para: Each (non-calculated) can contain zero or more s which are used for filtering and grouping by a specific value.

Except using fields defined in Pivot Table data source (more precisely, in ) which cannot be removed, Pivot Table can also define calculated s and calculated s which use a formula to specify their values. Calculated can be added using a method and removed using a method. Property tells if a field is calculated or is a field from the data source. Calculated is automatically moved to a Values Area ( collection) and only Values Area can contain calculated s. Calculated can be added using a method and removed using a method. Property tells if an item is calculated.

note.para: If calculated is added/removed in one , then it is also added/removed from all other s which reference the same .
Since adding/removing calculated s means changing the data scheme, which is defined in , actual modification is made in and propagated to all s which are referencing it.

remarks.para: s can be re-ordered in a specific area using the method. s can be re-ordered using the method.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently does not provide functionality to read/calculate the actual data from the .
It provides the functionality to arrange and customize s, s and appearance.

Because of that data is not rendered/written to other output formats like PDF, HTML, etc. When output XLSX file with Pivot Table is opened in Microsoft Excel application, its data is automatically retrieved and calculated from the data source by Microsoft Excel.

member.seealso: Create Excel Pivot Tables in C# and VB.NET

remarks.para: s can be re-ordered in a specific area using the method. s can be re-ordered using the method.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently does not provide functionality to read/calculate the actual data from the .
It provides the functionality to arrange and customize s, s and appearance.

Because of that data is not rendered/written to other output formats like PDF, HTML, etc. When output XLSX file with Pivot Table is opened in Microsoft Excel application, its data is automatically retrieved and calculated from the data source by Microsoft Excel.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PivotTables.PivotCacheCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of all objects in the workbook.

remarks.para: Pivot Tables are used to arrange and aggregate complicated data and drill down on details.
Source of data for Pivot Table can be:

item.description: Worksheet - cell range, named range, table, etc.
External - database, OLAP cube, textual file, web query, etc.
Other - multiple consolidation ranges in the workbook, another Pivot Table, etc.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently supports creating only worksheet source.
All other sources are supported through preservation (to correctly round-trip to XLSX format).

remarks.para: Source of the data for Pivot Table contains following information:

item.description: Scheme - data source fields/columns, its data types, etc.
Data - actual data source records.

remarks.para: Pivot Table does not directly reference its data source, but instead it references a cache of a data source. Cache of a data source contains an in-memory copy of data source scheme and, optionally, data and is stored in a workbook which may contain multiple caches of various sources of data.

Cache can be updated/refreshed from a data source automatically (for example, when opening a workbook) or on request. Cache is used to provide better performance of Pivot Table functionality which requires frequent access to data records and their values and to enable sharing the same data source between multiple Pivot Tables.

GemBox.Spreadsheet represents cache with a type. Cache source is represented with a type (and its sub-types) and can be accessed from a property. instances are stored in a collection. currently doesn't store the actual cached records (it stores only scheme - fields and their properties), but instead Microsoft Excel is instructed to update the record cache from the data source when opening a workbook.

is created from a with the specified name and the specified cell in the worksheet where it is placed using the method. contains the collection which elements can be moved into the following Pivot Table areas:

item.description: Report Filter Area represented by collection.
Row Axis represented by collection.
Column Axis represented by collection.
Values Area represented by collection.

remarks.para: Each (non-calculated) can contain zero or more s which are used for filtering and grouping by a specific value.

Except using fields defined in Pivot Table data source (more precisely, in ) which cannot be removed, Pivot Table can also define calculated s and calculated s which use a formula to specify their values. Calculated can be added using a method and removed using a method. Property tells if a field is calculated or is a field from the data source. Calculated is automatically moved to a Values Area ( collection) and only Values Area can contain calculated s. Calculated can be added using a method and removed using a method. Property tells if an item is calculated.

note.para: If calculated is added/removed in one , then it is also added/removed from all other s which reference the same .
Since adding/removing calculated s means changing the data scheme, which is defined in , actual modification is made in and propagated to all s which are referencing it.

remarks.para: s can be re-ordered in a specific area using the method. s can be re-ordered using the method.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently does not provide functionality to read/calculate the actual data from the .
It provides the functionality to arrange and customize s, s and appearance.

Because of that data is not rendered/written to other output formats like PDF, HTML, etc. When output XLSX file with Pivot Table is opened in Microsoft Excel application, its data is automatically retrieved and calculated from the data source by Microsoft Excel.

member.seealso: Create Excel Pivot Tables in C# and VB.NET

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PivotTables.PivotItem
member.summary: Represents an item in a .

remarks.para: Pivot Tables are used to arrange and aggregate complicated data and drill down on details.
Source of data for Pivot Table can be:

item.description: Worksheet - cell range, named range, table, etc.
External - database, OLAP cube, textual file, web query, etc.
Other - multiple consolidation ranges in the workbook, another Pivot Table, etc.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently supports creating only worksheet source.
All other sources are supported through preservation (to correctly round-trip to XLSX format).

remarks.para: Source of the data for Pivot Table contains following information:

item.description: Scheme - data source fields/columns, its data types, etc.
Data - actual data source records.

remarks.para: Pivot Table does not directly reference its data source, but instead it references a cache of a data source. Cache of a data source contains an in-memory copy of data source scheme and, optionally, data and is stored in a workbook which may contain multiple caches of various sources of data.

Cache can be updated/refreshed from a data source automatically (for example, when opening a workbook) or on request. Cache is used to provide better performance of Pivot Table functionality which requires frequent access to data records and their values and to enable sharing the same data source between multiple Pivot Tables.

GemBox.Spreadsheet represents cache with a type. Cache source is represented with a type (and its sub-types) and can be accessed from a property. instances are stored in a collection. currently doesn't store the actual cached records (it stores only scheme - fields and their properties), but instead Microsoft Excel is instructed to update the record cache from the data source when opening a workbook.

is created from a with the specified name and the specified cell in the worksheet where it is placed using the method. contains the collection which elements can be moved into the following Pivot Table areas:

item.description: Report Filter Area represented by collection.
Row Axis represented by collection.
Column Axis represented by collection.
Values Area represented by collection.

remarks.para: Each (non-calculated) can contain zero or more s which are used for filtering and grouping by a specific value.

Except using fields defined in Pivot Table data source (more precisely, in ) which cannot be removed, Pivot Table can also define calculated s and calculated s which use a formula to specify their values. Calculated can be added using a method and removed using a method. Property tells if a field is calculated or is a field from the data source. Calculated is automatically moved to a Values Area ( collection) and only Values Area can contain calculated s. Calculated can be added using a method and removed using a method. Property tells if an item is calculated.

note.para: If calculated is added/removed in one , then it is also added/removed from all other s which reference the same .
Since adding/removing calculated s means changing the data scheme, which is defined in , actual modification is made in and propagated to all s which are referencing it.

remarks.para: s can be re-ordered in a specific area using the method. s can be re-ordered using the method.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently does not provide functionality to read/calculate the actual data from the .
It provides the functionality to arrange and customize s, s and appearance.

Because of that data is not rendered/written to other output formats like PDF, HTML, etc. When output XLSX file with Pivot Table is opened in Microsoft Excel application, its data is automatically retrieved and calculated from the data source by Microsoft Excel.

member.seealso: Create Excel Pivot Tables in C# and VB.NET

remarks.para: s can be re-ordered in a specific area using the method. s can be re-ordered using the method.

note.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet currently does not provide functionality to read/calculate the actual data from the .
It provides the functionality to arrange and customize s, s and appearance.

Because of that data is not rendered/written to other output formats like PDF, HTML, etc. When output XLSX file with Pivot Table is opened in Microsoft Excel application, its data is automatically retrieved and calculated from the data source by Microsoft Excel.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat
member.summary: An enumeration of supported pixel formats when saving an to an image using an .

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Default
member.summary: Pixel format that is best suited for the particular operation.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Bgr101010
member.summary: Bgr101010 is a sRGB format with 32 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel (blue, green, and red) is allocated 10 bits per pixel (BPP).

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Bgr24
member.summary: Bgr24 is a sRGB format with 24 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel (blue, green, and red) is allocated 8 bits per pixel (BPP).

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Bgr32
member.summary: Bgr32 is a sRGB format with 32 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel (blue, green, and red) is allocated 8 bits per pixel (BPP).

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Bgr555
member.summary: Bgr555 is a sRGB format with 16 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel (blue, green, and red) is allocated 5 bits per pixel (BPP).

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Bgr565
member.summary: Bgr565 is a sRGB format with 16 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel (blue, green, and red) is allocated 5, 6, and 5 bits per pixel (BPP) respectively.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Bgra32
member.summary: Bgra32 is a sRGB format with 32 bits per pixel (BPP). Each channel (blue, green, red, and alpha) is allocated 8 bits per pixel (BPP).

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.BlackWhite
member.summary: Black and white pixel format which displays one bit of data per pixel as either black or white.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Cmyk32
member.summary: Cmyk32 pixel format which displays 32 bits per pixel (BPP) with each color channel (cyan, magenta, yellow, and black) allocated 8 bits per pixel (BPP).

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Gray16
member.summary: Gray16 pixel format which displays a 16 bits-per-pixel grayscale channel, allowing 65536 shades of gray. This format has a gamma of 1.0.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Gray2
member.summary: Gray2 pixel format which displays a 2 bits-per-pixel grayscale channel, allowing 4 shades of gray.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Gray32Float
member.summary: Gray32Float displays a 32 bits per pixel (BPP) grayscale channel, allowing over 4 billion shades of gray. This format has a gamma of 1.0.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Gray4
member.summary: Gray4 pixel format which displays a 4 bits-per-pixel grayscale channel, allowing 16 shades of gray.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Gray8
member.summary: Gray8 pixel format which displays an 8 bits-per-pixel grayscale channel, allowing 256 shades of gray.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Pbgra32
member.summary: Pbgra32 is a sRGB format with 32 bits per pixel (BPP). Each channel (blue, green, red, and alpha) is allocated 8 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel is pre-multiplied by the alpha value.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Prgba128Float
member.summary: Prgba128Float is a ScRGB format with 128 bits per pixel (BPP). Each channel (red, green, blue, and alpha) is allocated 32 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel is pre-multiplied by the alpha value. This format has a gamma of 1.0.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Prgba64
member.summary: Prgba64 is a sRGB format with 64 bits per pixel (BPP). Each channel (blue, green, red, and alpha) is allocated 32 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel is pre-multiplied by the alpha value. This format has a gamma of 1.0.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Rgb128Float
member.summary: Rgb128Float is a ScRGB format with 128 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel is allocated 32 BPP. This format has a gamma of 1.0.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Rgb24
member.summary: Rgb24 is a sRGB format with 24 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel (red, green, and blue) is allocated 8 bits per pixel (BPP).

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Rgb48
member.summary: Rgb48 is a sRGB format with 48 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel (red, green, and blue) is allocated 16 bits per pixel (BPP). This format has a gamma of 1.0.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Rgba128Float
member.summary: Rgba128Float is a ScRGB format with 128 bits per pixel (BPP). Each color channel is allocated 32 bits per pixel (BPP). This format has a gamma of 1.0.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PixelFormat.Rgba64
member.summary: Rgba64 is an sRGB format with 64 bits per pixel (BPP). Each channel (red, green, blue, and alpha) is allocated 16 bits per pixel (BPP). This format has a gamma of 1.0.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PrintOptions.MetafileScaleFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the scaling factor for rendering metafile (WMF and EMF) images. Greater scaling factor improves quality but also increases file size. Default value is 1.
member.value: The metafile scale factor for rendering metafile (WMF and EMF) images.

remarks.para: Windows Metafile Format (WMF) and Enhanced Metafile Format (EMF) are vector image formats which contain a series of graphics drawing commands usually executed in Windows GDI layer.
Metafile drawing commands could also be executed in PDF (or XPS) file which is also vector format, but for that Metafile drawing commands would have to be converted to PDF drawing commands.

GemBox.Document currently doesn't perform this conversion of drawing commands, instead it uses Windows GDI to execute Metafile drawing commands into bitmap which is then encoded to PNG format and embedded into PDF file.
specifies the size of the bitmap surface, based from the original Metafile surface size, into which Metafile should be drawn / rasterized.

PDF viewer will still scale the bitmap to the original Metafile size, but if the page is zoomed or viewed on a larger surface, quality of the image will be better since it contains more pixels / dots which will become visible while PDF viewer scales down the image.

increases the quality of the Metafile image in PDF file, but it also increases the size of the PDF file because greater means greater bitmap surface and more space to store bitmap pixel / color data. PNG encoding / compression helps in reducing the space requirement and for complex Metafiles (with a lot of drawing instructions), of 5 or even greater, might not incur any space overhead relative to the original (complex) Metafile.
Default value for is 1.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.PrintOptions.DocumentName

summary.para: Gets or sets the name of the printed document in the print queue.
Default value is 'Spreadsheet'.

member.value: The name of the printed document in the print queue.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ProtectedRange
member.summary: Represents a range of cells to be protected.

remarks.para: Ranges listed here are protected only when the sheet protection is ON and the cell is flagged as being locked.If no password is specified here, then read/write permissions are automatically given to all users, regardless of additional security descriptor information. In other words, the security descriptor information (specific types of access) at the user level is only applied if a password for this range is specified.

When a password is specified, then users not listed specifically as having access should be prompted with a password.If that user supplies the correct password, then they can edit the range or cell in question.This protection is optional and can be ignored by applications that choose not to support this functionality.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ScriptPosition
member.summary: Defines the possible settings for vertical alignment of a text and is used in member to get superscript or subscript text without altering the font size.

remarks.para: Conceptually, cell formatting is divided into following groups:

item.description: Number - indicates how to format and render the numeric value of a cell. Associated property is .
Alignment - formatting information pertaining to text alignment in cells. Associated properties are , , , , , and .
Font - defines the properties for the used font. Associated property is .
Border - expresses a single set of cell border formats (left, right, top, bottom and diagonal). Associated property is .
Fill - specifies fill formatting (pattern or gradient). Associated property is .
Protection - contains protection properties associated with the cell. Associated properties are and .

remarks.para: Additional properties not associated with any formatting group are:

item.description: - name of the referenced workbook style.
- to store numeric value of a cell as text; otherwise, .
- if referenced workbook style is default () and there are no additional modifications of cell formatting; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Workbook contains a set of master styles which can be referenced by multiple cells.
Workbook must always contain at least one master style which cannot be removed and is, by default, referenced by all cells. This default style is .
Workbook style can either be built-in or user-defined. Built-in style is accessible from workbook styles via enumeration.

Cell formatting group (Number, Alignment, Font, Border, Fill or Protection) (and its associated properties) is resolved from referenced workbook (master) style, unless cell formatting group or its associated property is modified.

Cell formatting is available for one or more cells through property which is available on and types. Cell formatting specified on and types through property is simply propagated to cell formatting of its .

note.para: For performance reasons, cell formatting on is resolved based just on its top-left cell formatting, except borders which are resolved based on corner cells depending on border side.
Setting cell formatting property on is propagated to each cell in a range.

remarks.para: To set workbook (master) style to one or more cells, simply assign it to property.

note.para: Preferable way to modify formatting property of multiple cells is to get to which all those cells belong, and use property of that range to make the modification.

If modifying multiple formatting properties of a , without preserving unmodified formatting properties, preferable way is to create new instance of , make modifications on it, and assign it to property of that range.

remarks.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet internally takes care not to allocate unnecessary cells when formatting a range of cells (for example, when formatting all worksheet cells) and to cache formatting information of equally formatted cells, at the appropriate time, to reduce memory footprint.

member.name: F:GemBox.Spreadsheet.ScriptPosition.Normal
member.summary: Returns the text to the baseline, default, alignment, and returns it to the original font size.

summary.para: Specifies that text should be superscript.
Raises the text above the baseline and changes it to a smaller size.
Specifies that text should be subscript.
Lowers the text below the baseline and changes it to a smaller size.

member.summary: Represents a spreadsheet color.

remarks.para: Spreadsheet color can either be empty / none, automatic, theme, standard or custom.
Empty, automatic, theme and standard colors can be created using the factory method which accepts parameter.

System.Drawing.Color nor any other, technology-specific, color type wasn't deliberately used, because GemBox.Spreadsheet public interface is exposed only through GemBox.Spreadsheet and .NET BCL (base class library) types.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.SpreadsheetInfo
member.summary: Contains static licensing methods and diagnostic information about executing GemBox.Spreadsheet assembly.

member.name: E:GemBox.Spreadsheet.SpreadsheetInfo.FreeLimitReached
member.summary: Occurs in loading or saving when GemBox.Spreadsheet assembly is used with FREE-LIMITED-KEY license key and free limit is reached.
member.remarks:
This event is raised when GemBox.Spreadsheet assembly is used with FREE-LIMITED-KEY license key and maximum number of rows (150 rows) or sheets (5 sheets) are reached.
            
Free mode will read / write first 150 rows/5 sheets normally and, if file has more than 150 rows or 5 sheets, it will throw .
You can use this event to continue using the assembly in a trial mode for performance testing (set  to 
            ) or to stop further reading/writing (set  to 
            ).
Trial mode will read and write all file content but will insert word "TRIAL" on random places in the file.
For more information about GemBox.Spreadsheet evaluation and licensing, see evaluation and licensing.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.SpreadsheetInfo.Title
member.summary: GemBox.Spreadsheet assembly title.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.SpreadsheetInfo.FullVersion
member.summary: GemBox.Spreadsheet assembly full version.

member.name: M:GemBox.Spreadsheet.SpreadsheetInfo.SetLicense(System.String)
member.summary: Call this method from your application to set GemBox.Spreadsheet serial key.

remarks.para: You should call this method before using any other class from GemBox.Spreadsheet library. Key can only be set once (if you try second key, it will be ignored). The best place to call this method is from static constructor of your application's main class.
Valid serial key has multiple groups of alphanumeric characters, separated with dashes.
Free version serial key is: FREE-LIMITED-KEY.

member.param: Serial key.

member.name: T:GemBox.Spreadsheet.Style
member.summary: Represents a workbook (master) style which can be shared by multiple cells.

remarks.para: Conceptually, cell formatting is divided into following groups:

item.description: Number - indicates how to format and render the numeric value of a cell. Associated property is .
Alignment - formatting information pertaining to text alignment in cells. Associated properties are , , , , , and .
Font - defines the properties for the used font. Associated property is .
Border - expresses a single set of cell border formats (left, right, top, bottom and diagonal). Associated property is .
Fill - specifies fill formatting (pattern or gradient). Associated property is .
Protection - contains protection properties associated with the cell. Associated properties are and .

remarks.para: Additional properties not associated with any formatting group are:

item.description: - name of the referenced workbook style.
- to store numeric value of a cell as text; otherwise, .
- if referenced workbook style is default () and there are no additional modifications of cell formatting; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Workbook contains a set of master styles which can be referenced by multiple cells.
Workbook must always contain at least one master style which cannot be removed and is, by default, referenced by all cells. This default style is .
Workbook style can either be built-in or user-defined. Built-in style is accessible from workbook styles via enumeration.

Cell formatting group (Number, Alignment, Font, Border, Fill or Protection) (and its associated properties) is resolved from referenced workbook (master) style, unless cell formatting group or its associated property is modified.

Cell formatting is available for one or more cells through property which is available on and types. Cell formatting specified on and types through property is simply propagated to cell formatting of its .

note.para: For performance reasons, cell formatting on is resolved based just on its top-left cell formatting, except borders which are resolved based on corner cells depending on border side.
Setting cell formatting property on is propagated to each cell in a range.

remarks.para: To set workbook (master) style to one or more cells, simply assign it to property.

note.para: Preferable way to modify formatting property of multiple cells is to get to which all those cells belong, and use property of that range to make the modification.

If modifying multiple formatting properties of a , without preserving unmodified formatting properties, preferable way is to create new instance of , make modifications on it, and assign it to property of that range.

remarks.para: GemBox.Spreadsheet internally takes care not to allocate unnecessary cells when formatting a range of cells (for example, when formatting all worksheet cells) and to cache formatting information of equally formatted cells, at the appropriate time, to reduce memory footprint.

member.name: P:GemBox.Spreadsheet.Style.Hidden
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this style is hidden in the application UI.
member.value: if this style is hidden in the application UI; otherwise, .
